reasoning_chain:

So, for example, in a cube, if I pick one vertex, the opposite one would be the one you reach by moving along the space diagonal. That diagonal goes through the cube from one corner to the opposite corner, passing through the center of the cube.

So, if the plane is passing through these two opposite vertices, that already gives me a line along the space diagonal. Now, the plane also passes through the midpoints of two edges that don't contain either of those vertices. Hmm, so midpoints of edges. The resulting solid is a half-cylinder. The radius of the base of the cylinder is the length of the side opposite the 60° angle, which is \( 4\sqrt{3} \) units. The height of the cylinder is the length of the shortest side, which is 4 units.

To find the volume of the half-cylinder, I will use the formula for the volume of a cylinder and then account for the half:

\text{Volume} = \frac{1}{2} \times \pi \times r^2 \times h = \frac{1}{2} \times \pi \times (4\sqrt{3})^2 \times 4
\]
Calculating the values:
\[
(4\sqrt{3})^2 = 16 \times 3 = 48
\]
\[
\text{Volume} = \frac{1}{2} \times \pi \times 48 \times 4 = 96\pi
\]

problem: If you draw all diagonals of a regular hexagon, how many triangles are formed in total (counting all triangles of any size)?
reasoning_chain:

Now, when we draw all the diagonals, that means connecting every non-adjacent vertex to every other vertex, right?

First off, a cube has 8 corners and 12 edges. Each corner is connected to three other corners via edges. So, starting from one corner, the ant has three possible directions to go. In graph theory, the shortest path can be found using something called a breadth-first search (BFS). So, if I were to perform BFS on this cube graph starting from A, the first time I reach E would be the minimum number of edges needed.
